data.title: Reese Witherspoon's Daughter Ava Phillippe Calls Out 'Bulls**t' Body Shamers
data.meta_description: The young star called the hate over her appearance "toxic behavior."
data.text:
LOADINGERROR LOADING

Reese Witherspoonâ€™s daughter, Ava Phillippe, is shutting down the internet trolls who criticized her appearance.

Phillippe â€” the oldest child of Witherspoon and ex-husband and fellow actor Ryan Phillippe â€” shared a video on TikTok over the weekend to address the drama.

Advertisement

â€œNBD but I just achieved a major milestone as a woman online,â€ her message reads as she begins applying red lipstick in front of the mirror.

â€œI saw 2 different strangers commenting on my body. The first said I should get on Oz*mpic because Iâ€™m too fatâ€¦â€ she wrote, censoring the name of Ozempic, a diabetes drug that has become popular for weight loss.

â€œThe second accused me of starving myself because Iâ€™m too thin... My weight did not change in the time period between their comments. (& it wouldnâ€™t be any of their business if it did!),â€ her message continued in the Friday post.

The internet personality then smeared the lipstick across her cheek while rolling her eyes, adding, â€œItâ€™s such bullshit.â€

Advertisement

Ava Phillippe captioned her post, â€œPretty is as pretty does, babes â€¦ & bodyshaming is simply toxic behavior. ğŸ’‹.â€

She went on to clarify that body-shaming isnâ€™t confined to one gender.

â€œP.S. I put â€˜womanâ€™ because I see this type of thing happening disproportionately to young girls & women, but let me be clear; body shaming is toxic no matter who the subject is,â€ she explained. â€œWe all deserve to feel safe & at peace in the vessel we live in.â€

Ava Phillippeâ€™s Oscar-winning mom took to the comments section to co-sign her message, writing, â€œYes to all of this ğŸ’‹.â€

The young starâ€™s other TikTok followers also poured out support for her clapback in the comments section.

â€œI have never understood why people think they need to make comments about other peopleâ€™s bodies.. itâ€™s so, so unnecessary. love you, and this message!!ğŸ’š,â€ one person wrote.

Advertisement

Another person said, â€œI wish I would have heard this message as a young woman. I am so impressed with your wisdom and compassion.â€

â€œThis!!!! we as women do not need any of this toxicity/negativity,â€ someone else said. â€œWe should be building each other up not tearing each other down. btw, you are a light in this world and absolutely gorgeous â¤ï¸.â€

Ava Phillippe doubled down on her PSA about body-shaming in her Instagram stories.
